The fourth summary verse says:

Sufficient food, separately, not at the proper time, touching, not receiving, excellent food.
The training rule on eating in sequence, the thirty-first training rule on eating in sequence. At that time the Blessed One was in the Kalandaka Bamboo Grove by the pond in RÄjagá¹›ha.

At that time the Venerable MahÄmaudgalyÄyana constantly went from time to time to the hells, animal realms, hungry ghost realms, human realms, and heavenly realms with compassion and observation. In the hells he saw sentient beings suffering from having their bodies cut with swords, from the suffering of being burned by the flames of corpses, hot ashes, and burning charcoal, and so forth;ğŸ”½in the animal realm he saw them suffering from eating each other, and so forth;
in the realm of hungry ghosts he saw them suffering from various kinds of hunger and thirst, and so forth;
In the heavens, he saw the suffering of separation from loved ones upon falling;
In the human realm, he saw the various hardships of seeking clothing, food, and livelihood, as well as the suffering of killing and punishment.
Having seen this, he proclaimed to the four assemblies:
All people should know!
As I have seen the different destinies of the five realms, the rewards of suffering and happiness are all not false.

You should have faith and not give rise to doubt.ğŸ”½Those who experience suffering receive it due to evil karma, namely killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, up to wrong views, disrespecting the Three Jewels, deceiving and despising elders and relatives, lacking a compassionate mind and not upholding precepts. Due to these evil actions, one obtains the ripening of suffering.

Those who experience happy rewards receive them due to good karma, namely not killing, stealing, up to not holding wrong views, revering and having faith in the Three Jewels, respecting elders and relatives, possessing a compassionate mind and upholding precepts. Due to these good actions, one obtains the ripening of happiness.
Having heard this, the people exclaimed in admiration, saying:
Excellent!

The sage is able to do this for us blind and deluded ones, who only see the present and do not foresee the future. He personally observes good and evil matters in the five destinies and comes back to tell us. We now know that karmic retribution is like a shadow following a form and will certainly not be wasted.
From now on we will abandon evil and cultivate merit, hoping to be reborn in the good destinies and not fall into the evil destinies.
At that time, the four assemblies, having heard this, all thought:
Our sons, daughters, or disciples always engage in evil deeds and do not diligently practice pure and chaste conduct.
Wishing to make them abandon all evil deeds, they all brought them to the place of the sage MahÄmaudgalyÄyana and had them listen to the Dharma.
Having heard the Dharma, they hoped to cultivate good conduct and avoid falling into the evil destinies and attaining the supreme fruit.
At that time, the four assemblies gathered like clouds to listen to the essential Dharma. The crowd of people was noisy.
The World-Honored One, knowing this, deliberately asked Venerable Ä€nanda:
Why is it that MahÄmaudgalyÄyana is surrounded by the four assemblies?
At that time, Ä€nanda addressed the Buddha, saying:

World-Honored One, Venerable MahÄmaudgalyÄyana traveled through the five destinies and saw the various sufferings. He spoke about it in detail to the four assemblies. For this reason, all these people have come to gather to listen to the Dharma.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Ä€nanda:

Not at all times and places is there always MahÄmaudgalyÄyana. Such people are also quite difficult to find. Therefore, I now order the bhiká¹£us to paint the wheel of birth and death under the temple gate.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us did not know the painting method. The World-Honored One said:
You should make a wheel according to the size, with a hub in the center, and next place five spokes to represent the characteristics of the five destinies.
Below the hub, paint the hells, and on the two sides, paint the animals and hungry ghosts.
Next, above that, one can draw humans and gods. In the human realm, one should make the four continents:

Eastern Videha, Southern JambudvÄ«pa, Western GodÄnÄ«ya, and Northern Kuru. In the center, make a round white circle and draw an image of the Buddha. In front of the Buddha image, one should draw three kinds of forms:

First, make a dove-shaped image to represent excessive attachment to desire, next, make a snake-shaped image to represent excessive anger, and lastly, make a pig-shaped image to represent excessive ignorance. In the outer rim, one should make an irrigation wheel image with many water pots, and draw an image of sentient beings' birth and death.
Those who are born emerge from the top of the pot, and those who die emerge from the bottom of the pot. In the five realms,
each should be shaped like its form. Circling around, one should also draw the twelve links of dependent origination and the characteristics of birth and cessation, namely:
Ignorance conditions formations, up to old age and death. The link of ignorance should be made to resemble an evil spirit, the link of formations

The consciousness link should be made in the form of a monkey, the name-and-form link should be made in the form of a person on a boat, the six sense bases link should be made in the form of the six sense faculties, the contact link should be made in the form of a man and woman touching each other, the feeling link should be made in the form of a man and woman experiencing suffering and pleasure, the craving link should be made in the form of a womanğŸ”½ğŸ”½

The consciousness link should be made to resemble a monkey, the name-and-form link should be made to resemble a person on a boat, the six sense bases link should be made to resemble the six sense faculties, the contact link should be made to resemble a man and woman touching each other, the feeling link should be made to resemble a man and woman experiencing suffering and pleasure, the craving link should be made to resemble a woman holding a man and child, the grasping link should be made to resemble a man holding a jar to draw water, the existence link

should be made to resemble the god MahÄbrahmÄ, the birth link should be made to resemble a woman giving birth, the aging link should be made to resemble a man and woman in old age, the sickness should be made to resemble a man and woman with an illness, the death link should be made to resemble a palanquin carrying a dead person, the sorrow should be made to resemble a man and woman in grief, the lamentation should be made to resemble a man and woman crying, the suffering should be made to resemble a man and woman experiencing suffering, the distress should be made to resemble a man and woman pulling a recalcitrant camel.

On top of the wheel, one should draw a ghost of impermanence with disheveled hair, its mouth open, its two arms stretched out embracing the wheel of birth and death. On both sides of the ghost's head, write two verses, which say:
You should seek liberation, diligently practice the Buddha's teachings,
And subdue the army of birth and death, like an elephant destroying a grass hut.
In this Dharma and Vinaya, always be heedful,
You will be able to exhaust the ocean of afflictions and end the bounds of suffering.
Next, on top of the ghost of impermanence, one should draw a white circular altar to symbolize the perfect purity of nirvana.
As instructed by the Buddha, under the door eaves one should draw the wheel of birth and death. At that time, the monks obeyed the instruction and drew it.
The faithful Brahmins and householders saw the drawn wheel and asked,
Noble ones!
What does this drawn wheel symbolize?
The monks replied,ğŸ”½This is the wheel of birth and death.
I also do not know what to depict.
The people replied:
If you do not understand, why draw it?
At that time, the bhiká¹£us had nothing to say in response. They then went to the World-Honored One and reported this matter in detail.
The World-Honored One said:
You should appoint a bhiká¹£u to sit under the gatehouse and point out the causes and conditions of the wheel of birth and death to the coming and going people, brÄhmans, and others.

As instructed by the Buddha, the bhiká¹£us then did not select someone who was knowledgeable, but instead had someone who was ignorant guide them, which did not give rise to faith but instead attracted ridicule. The Buddha said:
Appoint someone who understands to point out to the people.
At that time, there was an elder in RÄjagá¹›ha who, not long after marrying, gave birth to a son. His appearance was upright and pleasing to the eyes. He told his wife:
Wise one!
Now that I have a son, there will be many expenses. You should go to the great ocean to seek precious goods.
His wife said:
Good.
The elder then took various goods and entered the great ocean. Due to the wind, the ship was wrecked and he went without returning.
His wife suffered hardship, either relying on relatives or using her own strength to raise the young child. Because of being orphaned and poor, the child was named Poorly Born.
At that time, the young boy Poorly Born gradually grew up, was entrusted to a teacher to study, and then went with his classmates to the Bamboo Grove.
Arriving at the temple gate, he saw a painted wheel of the five destinies and the cycle of birth and death, and asked:
Noble one!
What is this called?
The bhiká¹£u replied:
This is the wheel of the five destinies and the cycle of birth and death.
He said:
Noble one!
Please explain it to me.
The bhiká¹£u said:
You should listen well!
Namely, the distinctions of the destinies of hell beings, animals, hungry ghosts, humans, and gods.
He also asked:
Noble one!
What karma did these hell beings create that they experience the suffering of having their bodies cut and smashed?
The bhiká¹£us replied:
Wise ones!
They committed the ten evil karmic paths with the most serious mind, repeatedly and without rest. Due to the power of that karma, they now experience this suffering.
They further asked:
Noble ones!
What karma did these animals create that they experience the suffering of carrying heavy loads and eating each other?
The bhiká¹£us replied:
Wise ones!
They committed the ten evil karmic paths with a light mind, repeatedly and without rest. Due to the power of that karma, they now experience this suffering.
They further asked:
Noble ones!
What karma did these hungry ghosts create that they experience the suffering of hunger, thirst, and burning?
The bhiká¹£us replied:
Wise ones!

This is due to being stingy with one's own possessions, unwilling to give in charity, seeing others giving and then trying to stop them, having no intention to distribute to the Three Jewels, parents, and relatives, and doing so repeatedly. By the power of that karma, one now experiences this suffering.
He asked again:
Noble one!
What karma did these heavenly beings create in the past to experience supreme bliss?
The bhiká¹£u replied:
Wise one!

This is due to cultivating the ten wholesome deeds with a sincere mind, respectfully believing in the Three Jewels, and upholding the precepts. By the power of that karma, they are now reborn in the heavens and experience supreme bliss.
He asked again:
Noble one!
What karma did these human beings create in the past to experience moderate happiness, but also have the suffering of striving to make a living?
The bhiká¹£u replied:
Wise one!

Here, with a light and subtle mind, one repeatedly cultivates the ten wholesome courses of action. By the power of that karma, one now obtains a human body and experiences moderate happiness, but there is the suffering of seeking a livelihood and so forth.
The youth said:
Noble one!
I do not wish for the three lower realms, but have admiration for being born among humans and gods.
Noble one!
What karma should I create to be born in those heavens?
He replied:
If you are able to go forth in the well-taught Dharma and Vinaya of the Buddha, cultivate and practice with exertion in this very life, cut off all afflictions, and end the bounds of suffering,
if you do not attain the fruits but pass away with remaining afflictions, you will be born in the heavens.ğŸ”½ The youth said:
Noble one!
What karma should one create if going forth?
He replied:
Until the end of life, without violating the precepts.
He said:
I cannot do that. What other karma can be done to be born in the heavens?
If one observes the eight precepts and five precepts, one becomes a lay practitioner or lay devotee.
He said:
What does this mean?
He replied:
For one day and night, or for one's whole life, to refrain from killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, and false speech, etc.
He said:
I cannot do that either. What other deeds can I do to be reborn in the heavens?
He replied:
If one offers food and drink to the Buddha and the Sangha, by this meritorious cause one will be reborn in the heavens.
Noble one!
How much is needed to offer food and drink to the Buddha and the Sangha?
He replied:
Five hundred gold coins are needed.
Noble one!
This can be arranged.
He then rose from his seat, bowed at the feet [of the monk], and left.
Returning home, he said to his mother:
I went to the Bamboo Grove Monastery earlier, and under the temple gate I saw a painted wheel of the five destinies of birth and death, namely the hells, animals, hungry ghosts, humans, and gods.
I do not desire the lower three evil destinies, but I have a fondness for the upper two destinies. Mother, do you now wish to be born as a human or god?
The mother said:
I wish to.
If so, you should give me five hundred gold coins to make a middling offering to the Buddha and Sangha, and you will be born in the heavens.
The mother said:

You lost your father when young, and were raised alone. Whether by your own efforts or relying on relatives, you have now become an adult and are entrusted to a teacher to study. The tuition has not even been fully paid, so where can you suddenly get five hundred gold coins?
He said:
If we are poor and do not have it, I will work to seek out the gold coins.
The mother said:
You are young now and have little strength. How can you work as a guest and seek precious wealth?
He replied:
I will do my best and hope to be like others.
Seeing his sincerity, his mother let him go. He went to the market to seek his own hire.

At that time, there were Brahmins and householders who came to look for workers, but he was never seen or asked. Even until dusk, he stood in the street as the people dispersed, and then he returned home.
His mother asked:
Did you find a place to work?
He replied:
No one has seen or asked me.
His mother said:
How can there be a worker like you, with your hair tied up?
For ordinary workers, their heads are covered in dust, wearing tattered and worn-out clothes. Others see them in the work area and ask about them.
The next morning, he did as his mother said, wearing coarse clothes and staying in the work area.
At that time, an elder wanted to build a house and came to the street looking for laborers. He took other people away and did not ask the poor man.
At that time, the poor man said to the elder:
I also work for hire. Why don't you hire me?
The elder said:
Your appearance is delicate. How can you do manual labor?
He replied:
How can a laborer be paid first?
The elder said:
I will pay you in the evening.
The poor man said:
I will work for you. If my work is satisfactory in the afternoon, you should pay me the agreed price. If it is not satisfactory, you don't have to give me anything.
The elder took him home to work. The other laborers were not diligent, but only this poor man worked with all his might.
The other people said:
Judging from your appearance, you don't know how to work for hire. You can only get by. Why do you suffer yourself?

The poor man replied:ğŸ”½I am not like you. I am not a laborer by nature. I am a poor man who has fallen on hard times. I am not like you who have wives and children to support. I am alone and have no one to rely on. I am not like you who have many friends and relatives. I am alone and have no one to turn to. I am not like you who have a lot of wealth and property. I am poor and have nothing to rely on. I am not like you who have a lot of food and drink. I am hungry and thirsty. I am not like you who have a lot of clothes and bedding. I am cold and have nothing to cover myself with. I am not like you who have a lot of entertainment and amusement. I am bored and have nothing to do. I am not like you who have a lot of friends and acquaintances. I am lonely and have no one to talk to. I am not like you who have a lot of fame and reputation. I am unknown and have no one to praise me. I am not like you who have a lot of power and influence. I am weak and have no one to protect me. I am not like you who have a lot of knowledge and wisdom. I am ignorant and have no one to teach me. I am not like you who have a lot of skills and abilities. I am clumsy and have
Do you know, brothers,
that because of my evil karma I was born into a poor family, and now if I deceive others again, where will I be reborn?
The others replied:
You don't understand yet. Just work hard for now. Before long, you'll be lazier than us.

At that time, the poor man was good at speaking and could skillfully explain things to the workers. The workers enjoyed listening to him and followed him while working, not having time to walk slowly because they wanted to listen to his words. The poor man led them until the end of the day, and the work done in one day was twice as much as usual.
The elder came in the evening to inspect the work. Seeing that it was twice as good as usual, he asked the workers:
Did you add more workers today?
They replied:
No, we didn't add any.
If not, why is it twice as much as before?
The workers told him the whole story. When the elder heard it, he was overjoyed and gave the poor man twice the usual wage.
The poor man asked:
How can you pay me for two days' work at once?
The elder said:
I feel ashamed of you, so I'm paying you double.
The poor man said:
If you are satisfied, then let me continue working until the house is finished. I don't need the wages right now, I'll take them all at once when it's done.
The elder said:
Excellent!

So he always had him working. When the house was finished, the elder calculated the money he wanted to pay him for the work, but he only had four hundred and fifty, not enough to meet his expectations.
When the poor man saw this, he began to cry. The elder said:
Why are you crying?
Have I deceived you?
He replied:ğŸ”½Elder, you have not deceived me, but I have deceived you. I have not worked for two days, but only one day and a half.

Elders and great men should not be deceived. However, my original intention was to seek five hundred coins to make offerings to the Buddha and Sangha. Since the money is not enough, I will have to suffer again. It is for this reason that I am crying sadly.
The elder said:
If it is for the sake of blessings, I wish to help accomplish it.
The poor man replied:
If the elder fills it up, it will become his own meritorious karma. It will go against my original vow and I will not be able to be reborn in the heavens.
The elder said:
Do you have faith and make offerings to the Buddha and Sangha?ğŸ”½He replied:
Yes, I do.
If so, you can go ask the World-Honored One. You should practice according to what the Buddha says.
Then the poor man went to where the Buddha was, bowed at the Buddha's feet, sat to one side, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

I hired myself out to serve a certain elder for many days in order to offer to the Buddha and the Sangha, seeking five hundred gold coins. When I finished the work, the five hundred coins were not enough.
The elder saw that I was short and added to make up the full amount. Should I take it or not?
Should I take it or not?
The Buddha said:
Young man!
You should take it.
He said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I fear that helping myself to others' things will prevent me from being reborn in the heavens.
The Buddha said:
Young man!

Since you were originally going to be reborn in the heavens when you first gave rise to the mind of enlightenment, how much more so for giving away your possessions, which will not prevent you from being reborn in the heavens?
After receiving the Buddha's teachings, he joyfully left. He went to the elder's house, took the five hundred gold coins, and returned to his mother, saying:
Kind mother!
Here are the five hundred gold coins. Please use them to make offerings to the Buddha and the Sangha.
His mother said:
Don't you know that our family is poor and lacks everything we need? We don't even have eating utensils or seats. If we want to invite the Buddha and the Sangha, how can we manage it?
You can go and tell the wealthy householder who hires laborers to let him know that our house is spacious and he may be able to help us.
The poor man heard this and went to the wealthy householder, saying:

Now our family is poor and lacks everything we need. We don't even have eating utensils or seats. We want to invite the Buddha and the Sangha, but we can't manage it. We dare to rely on you and use your house to prepare what we need, inviting the Buddha and the Sangha. Can we do this?
The wealthy householder thought:
If I build a new house and can make offerings to the Buddha and the Sangha, this will be a good deed.
He said:
You can leave your things here and go invite the Buddha and the Sangha. Come to my house to receive the offerings.
Then the poor man left his things there and went to the Buddha. He bowed at the Buddha's feet, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and said:
World-Honored One!
I only wish that you would deign to accept a humble meal at my house tomorrow.
At that time, the World-Honored One silently accepted the invitation.
Seeing that the Buddha had accepted, he bowed at the Buddha's feet and left. He reported the time to the elder.

The elder then prepared various kinds of excellent food and drink. In the morning, he laid out seats and cushions, placed a large water vessel, arranged incense and flowers, and sent a messenger to inform the Buddha:
The food and drink are ready. May the Buddha know the time.
At that time, the World-Honored One, at the beginning of the day, put on his robe, took his bowl, and went with the assembly of sages to the elder's house.
At that time, the six monks asked the attendant:
Whose house invited the Buddha and the assembly of monks today?
He replied:
The son of a certain elder.
The six monks discussed:

When they arrived at that house, they said:
Noble ones!
You may eat the light meal.
They all ate until full and then went to the invitation.
At that time, the World-Honored One and the great assembly arrived at the elder's house, washed their feet, and sat down in order.

At that time, the poor man then used pure, excellent, and wonderful food and drink, personally serving it himself, causing them all to eat until full. Seeing that the six Saá¹…gha members could not eat much, he went to the Buddha and said:
World-Honored One!
I see that among the assembly there are noble ones who cannot eat much. Will this not obstruct my rebirth in the heavens?

Wise one!
Merely offering seats and cushions will definitely cause rebirth in the heavens, let alone the Buddha and Saá¹…gha accepting food and drink.

At that time, the poor man saw that the Buddha and the Saá¹…gha had finished their meal, put away their bowls and utensils, then took a small seat in front of the Buddha, and listened to the wonderful Dharma.

At that time, there were five hundred merchants who had come from the great ocean and passed through RÄjagá¹›ha. On the first day of their arrival, they encountered a great festival. Their precious goods were not sold, so they discussed among themselves, saying:

After inquiring, they learned that the house of a certain elder had already offered food to the Buddha and monks. We should go there and redeem it with a price.
They then went to the house and said:
Elder!
The Buddha and monks have finished eating and there will certainly be leftovers. How much do you want to redeem them for?
The elder replied:ğŸ”½I do not want any price.

The poor man said:

At that time, all the merchants ate to their heart's content, and when they were full, they all praised him and said to the elder:
You have gained great blessings today. You have offered food to the Buddha and the Sangha in your own house, and we merchants have also been satisfied.
The elder replied:
This is not my food, it is the offering prepared by this young man.
They asked:
Whose son is this young man?
He replied:
He is the son of a certain elder.
The merchant leader said:
This man is the son of my friend.
He then spread out a large piece of cloth on the ground, along with precious treasures, and announced to everyone:
You should know!
I have heard that many threads make a cloth, and drops of water fill a vessel. If you have something to give, you should put it here.
In a short while, it turned into a pile of treasures.
The caravan leader said:
You should accept these things.
The poor man said:
I only gave food, I had no intention of seeking things.
The caravan leader said:
This is not the price of food. One treasure here can provide a hundred offerings. It has nothing to do with the price of food. It is a gift of joy.
He replied:
I prepared this meal seeking to be reborn in the heavens. Although you have given it to me, I dare not accept it. Do not let this hinder my rebirth in the heavens.
The caravan leader said:
Do you have faith in the Buddha?
He replied:
I have faith.
If you have faith in the Buddha, you should go ask the Buddha. You should follow the Buddha's teachings and put them into practice.
Then the elder's son went to where the Buddha was, bowed at the Buddha's feet, and said:
World-Honored One!
I prepared offerings earlier and still had leftover food, which I fed to five hundred merchants, all of whom were satisfied.
At that time, he was delighted and gave me many precious treasures. Should I accept these things or not?
The Buddha said:
Accept them.
He said:
World-Honored One!
Do not let these treasures hinder my rebirth in the heavens!
The Buddha said:
This is the flower-like retribution, the fruit-like retribution will come later.
Then the elder son bowed to the Buddha and left to receive the precious treasures.
At that time, in the city of RÄjagá¹›ha, there was an elder who was the head of the city, who fell ill and passed away without any sons. The people discussed:
Since the elder has died, there is no one to be the head. Whom should we find to lead and unite us?
We should find a very meritorious person to make him the head.
The people discussed:
How can we know who has great merit?
Among them, a wise person said to the people:
You should place many seeds in a jar and have those people reach in with their hands to pick them out.
If someone gets a seed of a single color, we will appoint that person as the head.
They did as discussed, placing mixed seeds in a jar, and the people each picked out mixed seeds, but this poor man alone got pure-colored seeds.
Although the people saw this, they all discussed:
How can we appoint a hired laborer as the head?
So they had him pick three times, and he got pure-colored seeds all three times.
The people, seeing this, gave rise to a sense of wonder and said:
This must be the protection of the heavenly spirits. We should now all together request him to be our leader.
At that time, the village and town all appointed the poor man as their head.

The elder who prepared the offerings saw this and immediately adorned his daughter with various precious necklaces and betrothed her to him. At that time, due to the power of the poor man's good karma, precious treasures suddenly appeared in his house. People called him Good Birth because of this.
At that time, the elder Good Birth had this thought:
The rewards I have received in my house are all due to the majestic power of the World-Honored One. I should now invite the Buddha and the Sangha to come to my house to accept my offerings.

Then the elder Good Birth went to where the Buddha was, bowed at the Buddha's feet, sat to one side, and the Buddha expounded the Dharma for him. After hearing the Dharma, he immediately rose, knelt on one knee, arranged his robes over one shoulder, joined his palms in respect, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I only wish that you would take pity on me and accept, together with the bhiká¹£us, my humble offerings tomorrow in my house.
At that time, the World-Honored One silently accepted.
The elder Suprabha, having seen the Buddha accept the food, immediately bowed at the Buddha's feet and left his seat.
Then, the elder Suprabha, that very night, prepared various kinds of excellent food and drink, as described in detail above, and personally offered it to the Buddha and the assembly of monks.
Seeing that the Buddha had finished his meal, he wished to listen to the Dharma, so he brought a small seat and sat in front of the Buddha.

At that time, the World-Honored One, knowing the inclinations and faculties of the elder, spoke the Dharma according to his capacity, causing the elder's mind to be enlightened. While sitting there, the couple, using the adamantine wisdom-hammer, destroyed the mountain of the twenty kinds of satkÄya-dá¹›á¹£á¹­i, and attained the fruit of stream-entry.
Having seen the truth, they said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
We have attained the fruit of liberation through the Buddha. This is not something that our parents, ancestors, kings, gods, Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, friends, or relatives could accomplish.

I have encountered the World-Honored One, the great spiritual friend, and have been rescued from the realms of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts, and have been placed in the excellent realms of humans and gods. I will end suffering and attain the bliss of nirvana, dry up the ocean of blood, and transcend the mountain of bones. All the views of self that have been accumulated since beginningless time will be completely eliminated, and I will attain the first fruit.

I now take refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha. I only wish that the World-Honored One would bear witness that I am a male and female lay disciple. From this day forth until the end of my life, I will uphold the five precepts:
